Notes: Born Jewish. First pope. Apostle of Jesus. According to Catholic tradition he received the keys of the Kingdom of Heaven (Matthew 16:18–19). Feast day (Feast of Saints Peter and Paul) 29 June. The Catholic Church recognizes him as the first Bishop of Rome appointed by Christ. Also revered as saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 29 June.[4] St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City is named after him.
First Roman pope.[5] Feast day 23 September. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 7 June. Possibly mentioned in the New Testament (Second Epistle to Timothy 4:21).[6]
First Greek pope. Feast day 26 April. Once erroneously split into Cletus and Anacletus.[7]

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 35 AD Roma, Italy, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Feast day 23 November. The earliest Apostolic Father, issued 1 Clement which is said to be the basis of apostolic authority for the clergy. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 25 November. Possibly mentioned in the New Testament (Epistle to the Philippians 4:3).[8] He was martyred by being tied to an anchor and being thrown in the sea.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 30 AD Bethlehem, Iudaea, Roman Empire[birth 5]
Notes: Hellenized Jew. Said to have divided Rome into parishes, assigning a priest to each. Feast day of 26 October.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 75 AD Rome, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Inaugurated the custom of blessing houses with holy water. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 18 March.
Greek. Feast day of 6 April. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 10 August.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 67 AD Terra Nova, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Greek. Feast day of 5 January. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 22 February. Church Father St. Irenaeus called him a great martyr; the earliest attested martyrdom of pope after St. Peter.
Greek. Tradition holds he was martyred; feast day 11 January.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 81 AD Aquileia, Italy, Roman Empire[birth 6]
Notes: Roman, brother of Hermas. Martyred by sword; feast day 11 July. Decreed that Easter should only be celebrated on a Sunday.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 92 AD Emesa, Syria, Roman Empire[birth 7]
Notes: Hellenized Syrian; first Syrian pope. Tradition holds he was martyred; feast day 17 April. Decreed that priests are not allowed to have long hair.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 119 AD Fundi, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 6]
Notes: Greek. Tradition holds he was martyred; feast day 22 April. Declared that marriage was valid as a sacrament blessed by a priest; formally inaugurated Easter as an annual festival in Rome.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 130 AD Nicopolis, Epirus, Roman Empire[birth 8]
Notes: Greek. Tradition holds he was martyred; feast day 6 May.
Roman Berber; first pope to have been born on the continent of Africa. Known for excommunicating Theodotus of Byzantium. Quartodecimanism controversy.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 160 AD Rome, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Combated against the adoptionist heresies of the followers of Theodotus the Byzantium who were ruled by Theodotus and Asclepiodotus. Although not physically martyred (murdered), he is called a martyr for the suffering he endured.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 155 AD Rome, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Greek. Martyred; feast day 14 October.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 175 AD Rome, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 25 May.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 175 AD Rome, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. First to abdicate after exile to Sardinia by Emperor Maximinus Thrax. The Liberian Catalogue records his death on 28 September 235, the earliest exact date in papal history.[10][11]

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 180 AD Petelia, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Greek. Feast day 3 January. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 5 August.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 200 AD Rome, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Divided the communities of Rome into seven districts, each supervised by a deacon. Feast day 20 January. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 5 August.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 180 AD Rome, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Died as a martyr through extreme hardship; feast day 16 September.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 200 AD Rome, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Feast day 5 March.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 205 AD Rome, Italia, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Greek. Martyred by beheading; feast day 2 August. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with the same feast day.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 215 AD Athens, Achaea, Roman Empire[birth 3]
Notes: Greek. Martyred by beheading. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 10 August.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 200 AD Terra Nova, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Greek. Feast day 26 December.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 206 AD Rome, Italy Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Feast day 30 December.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 240 AD Luna, Italy, Roman Empire (Now Luni, Italy)
Notes: Roman. Feast day 8 December.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 245 AD Salona, Dalmatia, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Martyred by beheading (according to legend). Feast day 22 April. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 11 August.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 250 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Feast day 26 April. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 7 June.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 255 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire[birth 4]
Notes: Roman. Feast day 16 January. Banished from Rome under Maxentius (309).
Greek. Feast day 17 August. Banished by the emperor Maxentius, and died in exile.

Roman Berber. Feast day 10 January. First pope after the end of the persecution of Christians through the Edict of Milan (313 AD) issued by Constantine the Great. Presided over the Lateran council of 313.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 285 AD Fanum Sancti Angeli de Scala, Apulia et Calabria, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Feast day 31 December. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 2 January. Pope during the First Council of Nicaea (325), the first ecumenical council. Under him was built: the Archbasilica of Saint John Lateran, Santa Croce in Gerusalemme and Old St. Peter's Basilica. Stated to be the recipient of the Donation of Constantine, which was later shown to be a forgery.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 290 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. One of Mark's undertakings was to compile stories of the lives of martyrs and bishops before his time. There is some reason to believe he founded two churches in the area of Rome. One of them is still known to this day as the Church of San Marco, although it is greatly changed since his time. The other church was at the Catacomb of Balbina, a cemetery. Emperor Constantine gave gifts of land and furnishing for both buildings. Feast day 7 October.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 280 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. He was involved in the Arian controversy, supporting Athanasius of Alexandria.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 310 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Banished by the Arian-leaning Emperor Constantius II and later yielding to him. Earliest pope not canonized by the Latin Church. Revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 27 August.[12]

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 305 AD Egitania, Lusitania or Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. The first pope from modern-day Portugal. Patron of Jerome, commissioned the Vulgate translation of the Bible. Pope during the First Council of Constantinople (381), the second ecumenical council. Council of Rome (382). First pope to be the official head of the church after the Emperor Gratian abdicates the title of "Pontifex Maximus".

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 334 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. His famous letters—the earliest surviving texts of papal decretals—focus particularly on religious discipline and include decisions on baptism, consecration, ordination, penance, and continence. Siricius’ important decretal of 386 (written to Bishop Himerius of Tarragona), commanding celibacy for priests, was the first decree on this subject.[13]

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 340 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Instructed priests to stand and bow their heads as they read from the Gospels.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 378 AD Albanum, Latium et Campania, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Visigoth Sack of Rome (410) under Alaric I.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 370 AD Messurga, Lucania et Bruttii, Roman Empire
Notes: Greek.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 377 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman.

Roman. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 8 April. Pope during the Council of Ephesus (431), the third ecumenical council recognized by the Catholic, Eastern Orthodox, and Oriental Orthodox churches.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 390 AD Rome, Italy, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman.

Name: English· Latin: St Leo I(Leo the Great)LEO MAGNVS
Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 390 AD Etruria, Italia, Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Convinced Attila the Hun to turn back his invasion of Italy. Wrote the Tome which was instrumental in the Council of Chalcedon (451) and in defining the hypostatic union. Feast day 10 November. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 18 February.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 400 AD Sardinia, Italy, Western Roman Empire
Notes: Roman.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 430 AD Tibur, Italy, Western Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Papacy during the collapse of the Western Roman Empire and subsequent overtaking of Rome and Italy in general by Odoacer.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 440 AD Rome, Italy, Western Roman Empire
Notes: Imperial Roman pope. Sometimes called Felix II. Great-great-grandfather of pope Gregory I.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 410 AD Mons Ferratus, Quinquegentiani, Africa, Western Roman Empire
Notes: Roman Berber; the last pope to have been born on the continent of Africa. The first pope called the "Vicar of Christ".[14]

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 445 AD Rome, Italy, Western Roman Empire
Notes: Greek. Tried to end the Acacian schism but it resulted in the Laurentian schism. Earliest pope not canonized by either the Latin Church or the Eastern Church.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 460 AD Sardinia, Italy, Western Roman Empire
Notes: Roman.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 450 AD Frusino, Italy, Western Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Father of Pope Silverius. Acacian schism.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 470 AD Sena Iulia, Italy, Western Roman Empire
Notes: Roman.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 490 AD Samnium, Kingdom of Odoacer
Notes: Roman. Sometimes called Felix III. Built Santi Cosma e Damiano.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 490 AD Rome, Kingdom of Odoacer
Notes: Ostrogoth; first Germanic pope. Changed the numbering of the years in the Julian Calendar from Ab Urbe Condita to Anno Domini.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 473 AD Rome, Western Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. First pope not to use his personal name, as it was associated with a Roman god, Mercury.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 490 AD Rome, Kingdom of Odoacer
Notes: Roman. Feast days 22 April and 20 September. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 17 April.
Roman. Exiled; feast day 20 June, son of Hormisdas.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 500 AD Rome, Kingdom of Odoacer
Notes: Roman. Pope during the Second Council of Constantinople (553), the fifth ecumenical council recognized by the Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches.
Roman. Credited with the construction of the basilica of Santi Apostoli.
Roman. Second Pope not to use his personal name.
Roman.
Romanized Ostrogoth. Ordered the construction of the Basilica di San Lorenzo fuori le Mura.

Name: English· Latin: St Gregory I(Gregory the Great)GREGORIVS MAGNVS
Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 540 AD Rome, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Last imperial Roman Pope. Great-great-grandson of pope Felix III. The first formally to employ the titles Servus servorum Dei and Pontifex Maximus. Established the Gregorian chant. Feast day 3 September. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 12 March. Known as "the Father of Christian Worship". Known as "St. Gregory the Dialogist" in Eastern Orthodoxy.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 530 AD Blera, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. For the next two centuries the Roman popes were all controlled by the Byzantine Empire.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 540 AD Rome, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Greek.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 550 AD Marsica, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. First pope to bear the same name as his immediate predecessor. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 570 AD Rome, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Sometimes called Deusdedit. The first pope to use lead seals on papal documents, which in time came to be called papal bulls.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 575 AD Neapolis, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Roman.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 585 AD Ceperanum, Campania, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Named a heretic and anathematized by the Third Council of Constantinople. (680)

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 585 AD Rome, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Roman.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 587 AD Iadera, Dalmatia, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Roman.

Notes: Greek. The last pope from Palestine. Planned the Lateran Council of 649, but died before it could open.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 590 AD Near Tuder, Umbria, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Roman. Last pope recognized as a martyr. Feast day of 12 November. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 14 April.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 615 AD Rome, Duchy of Rome(formally Eastern Roman Empire)
Notes: Roman.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 600 Signia, Duchy of Rome(formally Eastern Roman Empire)
Notes: Roman.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 621 Rome, Duchy of Rome(formally Eastern Roman Empire)
Notes: Roman. Sometimes called Adeodatus, without a number, in reference to Adeodatus I sometimes being called Deusdedit. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 610 Rome, Duchy of Rome(formally Eastern Roman Empire)
Notes: Roman.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 577 Panormus, Sicily, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Greek. Also revered as a saint in Eastern Christianity, with a feast day of 20 February. Pope during the Third Council of Constantinople (680), the sixth ecumenical council accepted by the Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 611 Aydonum, Sicily, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Greek. Feast day 3 July.

Notes: Roman. Feast day 7 May.

Notes: Greek.

Notes: Hellenized Syrian. Introduced the singing of the Lamb of God at mass.[14]
Greek. The only pope who came from Asia Minor.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 655 Rossanum, Calabria, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Greek. The second pope to bear the same name as his immediate predecessor.
Syrian.
Syrian. Last pope to visit Greece while in office, until John Paul II in 2001.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 669 Rome, Duchy of Rome(Eastern Roman Empire)
Notes: Roman. Feast day 11 February. Held the Synod of Rome (721).
Syrian; the last pope from Syria. The third pope to bear the same name as his immediate predecessor. Last pope to have been born outside Europe until the election of Francis in 2013.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 679 Sancta Severina, Calabria, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Greek. Feast day 15 March. Built the church of Santa Maria sopra Minerva.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 714 Rome, Duchy of Rome(formally Eastern Roman Empire)
Notes: Roman. Sometimes called Stephen III. The Donation of Pepin. Brother of Paul I.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 700 Rome, Duchy of Rome(formally Eastern Roman Empire)
Notes: Roman. Brother of Stephen II.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 723 Syracuse, Sicily, Eastern Roman Empire
Notes: Greek. Sometimes called Stephen IV. He summoned the Lateran Council (769).

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 700–12 Rome, Duchy of Rome(formally Eastern Roman Empire)
Notes: Roman. Pope during the Second Council of Nicaea (787), the seventh ecumenical council accepted by the Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 750 Rome, Duchy of Rome(formally Eastern Roman Empire)
Notes: Roman. Crowned Charlemagne emperor on Christmas Day, 800, thereby initiating what would become the Holy Roman Empire, requiring the imprimatur of the pope for its ruler's legitimacy.
First pope born in Rome after breaking away from the Roman Empire. Sometimes called Stephen V.

Italian. Son of Bonosus and Episcopa Theodora. Credited with finding the body of Saint Cecilia in the Catacomb of Callixtus, building the basilica of Santa Cecilia in Trastevere and the church of Santa Maria in Domnica.
Italian.
Italian.
Italian. Rebuilt the atrium of St. Peter’s Basilica and in the newly decorated chapel transferred the body of Gregory I.

Lombard. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict.

Notes: Italian. Encouraged missionary activity.

Italian. First pope to be assassinated.
Italian. Erroneously also known as Martin II.
Italian. Feast day 8 July. Adrian I was possibly his ancestor.
Italian. Sometimes called Stephen VI.
Italian. In early 897 posthumously executed following the Cadaver Synod. His body was reburied with full Christian honors in 897.

Italian. Elected by the people of Rome, in opposition to Leo VIII who was appointed by Emperor Otto; he accepted his own deposition in 964 leaving Leo VIII as the sole pope.

Italian. His pontificate from 963 to 964 is considered illegitimate by today's Catholic Church. An appointee of Emperor Otto I, his pontificate occurred during the period known as the Saeculum obscurum.
Italian. Chronicled after his death as "the Good".

Notes: German.

Notes: German. In 1054, mutual excommunications of Leo IX and Patriarch of Constantinople Michael I Cerularius began the East–West Schism. The anathematizations were rescinded by Pope Paul VI and Patriarch Athenagoras in 1965.[15]

Notes: German.

Notes: German. Sometimes called Stephen X. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict.

Notes: French. In 1059 the College of Cardinals was designated the sole body of pope electors in the document In nomine Domini. (Papal conclave).

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 1018 Baggio, Milan, Holy Roman Empire
Notes: Italian. Authorised the Norman conquest of England in 1066.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 1015 Sovana, March of Tuscany, Holy Roman Empire
Notes: Lombard. Initiated the Gregorian Reforms. Restricted the use of the papal title to the bishop of Rome.[4] Member of the Order of Saint Benedict. Political struggle with Emperor Henry IV, who had to go to Canossa (1077).
Lombard. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict. Called the Synod of Benevento (1087) condemning lay investiture.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 1042 Châtillon-sur-Marne, County of Champagne, France
Notes: French. Preached and started the First Crusade. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 1050 Bleda, March of Tuscany, Holy Roman Empire
Notes: Lombard. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict. Ordered the building of the basilica of Santi Quattro Coronati.
Italian.
French. Opened the First Council of the Lateran in 1123.

Notes: Italian. Canon Regular of S. Maria di San Reno. Approved the new military order of the Knights Templar in 1128.
Italian. Canon regular of Lateran. Convened the Second Council of the Lateran, 1139.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 1085 Città di Castello, Papal States
Notes: Italian.
Italian. Canon Regular of S. Frediano di Lucca.
Italian. Member of the Order of Cistercians. Announced the Second Crusade.

Notes: The only English (Anglo-Saxon) pope; purportedly granted Ireland to Henry II, King of England. Canon Regular of St. Rufus Monastery.

Initiated the Fourth Crusade but later distanced himself from it and threatened participants with excommunication when it became clear that the leadership abandoned a focus on conquest of the Holy Land and instead intended to sack Christian cities.[18] Endorsed the Franciscan Order.
Italian. Initiated the Fifth Crusade. Approved several religious and tertiary orders.
Italian. Initiated the inquisition in France and endorsed the Northern Crusades.

Notes: Italian. Convened the First Council of Lyons (1245). Issued the bull Ad extirpanda that permitted the torture of heretics (1252).
Italian. Established an Inquisition in France.

Notes: French. Instituted the feast of Corpus Christi (1264).
French.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 1210 Piacenza, Italy, Holy Roman Empire
Notes: Italian. Convened the Second Council of Lyons (1274). Responsible for regulation all papal conclaves until the 20th century.

Notes: French. Member of the Dominican Order.

French.

Italian. Member of the Franciscan Order.

Notes: Italian. One of the few popes who abdicated voluntarily. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict. Founded the Celestines. Resigned from office and rumored to have been murdered in prison by Boniface VIII.

Motto: Illustra faciem Tuam super servum Tuum ("Let Your Face shine upon Your servant") Italian. Member of the Dominican Order. Reverted Boniface VIII's Unam Sanctam.

French. Pope at Avignon. Convened the Council of Vienne (1311–1312). Initiated the persecution of the Knights Templar with the bull Pastoralis Praeeminentiae under pressure from King Philip IV of France.

French. Pope at Avignon. Controversial for his views on the Beatific Vision. Opposed the Franciscan understanding of the poverty of Christ and his apostles, famously leading William of Ockham to write against unlimited papal power

Date_and_Place_of_birth: c. 1280–85 Saverdun, County of Foix, France
Notes: French. Pope at Avignon. Member of the Order of Cistercians. Known for issuing the Apostolic constitution Benedictus Deus (1336). A careful pope who reformed monastic orders and opposed nepotism.
French. Pope at Avignon. Reigned during the Black Death and absolved those who died of it of their sins.
French. Pope at Avignon. Through his exertions the Treaty of Brétigny (1360) was brought about.

French. Pope at Avignon. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict. Reformed areas of education and sent missionary movements across Europe and Asia. His pontificate witnessed the Alexandrian and Savoyard crusades.
French. Pope at Avignon; returns to Rome. The last French pope.
Italian. Western Schism. Last pontiff to be elected outside the College of Cardinals.
Italian. Western Schism.
Italian. Reigned during the Western Schism.
Italian. Reigned during the Western Schism.
Italian. His election effectively ended the Western Schism (1378–1417). Convened the Council of Basel (1431). Initiated the Hussite Wars.

Italian. Member of the Augustinian Order. Nephew of Gregory XII. Crowned Emperor Sigismund at Rome in 1433. Transferred the Council of Basel to Ferrara. It was later transferred again, to Florence, because of the Bubonic plague. Issued the bull "Creator Omnium", rescinding any recognition of Portugal's right to conquer those islands, still pagan. He excommunicated anyone who enslaved newly converted Christians, the penalty to stand until the captives were restored to their liberty and possessions

Italian. Held the Jubilee of 1450. Crowned Emperor Frederick III at Rome (1452). Issued the bull Dum Diversas allowing Portugal's right to conquer and subjugate Saracens and pagans (1452). Created a library in the Vatican which would eventually become the Bibliotheca Apostolica Vaticana.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 31 December 1378 Xàtiva, Kingdom of Valencia, Crown of Aragon
Notes: The first Spanish (Valencian) pope. Ordered the Feast of the Transfiguration to be celebrated on 6 August. Ordered the retrial of Joan of Arc, in which she was vindicated. Initiated the custom that bells be rung at midday to remind the faithful to pray for the crusaders. The tradition of the Angelus noon bell still exists in most Catholic Churches to this day. Appointed two nephews as cardinals, one of whom became Pope Alexander VI.
Italian. Displayed a great interest in urban planning. Founded Pienza near Siena as the ideal city in 1462. Known for his work on the Commentaries.
Italian. The nephew of Eugene IV. Built the Palazzo San Marco (now Palazzo Venezia). Approved the introduction of printing in the Papal States.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 21 July 1414 Celle Ligure, Republic of Genoa
Notes: Italian. Member of the Franciscan Order. Commissioned the Sistine Chapel and created the Vatican Archives. Authorized the Spanish Inquisition targeting converted Jewish Christians in Spain at the request of the Catholic Monarchs of Spain. A patron of the arts, he brought together the group of artists who ushered the Early Renaissance into Rome with the first masterpieces of the city's new artistic age. Noted for his nepotism and involved in the Pazzi conspiracy.
Italian. Appointed Tomás de Torquemada. Endorsed the prosecution of witchcraft in the bull Summis desiderantes affectibus (1484).

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 1 January 1431 Xàtiva, Kingdom of Valencia, Crown of Aragon
Notes: Spanish (Valencian); Nephew of Callixtus III; father to Cesare Borgia and Lucrezia Borgia. Divided the extra-European world between Spain and Portugal in the bull Inter caetera (1493). Considered one of the most controversial of the Renaissance popes, partly because he acknowledged fathering several children by his mistresses. As a result, his Italianized Valencian surname, Borgia, became a byword for libertinism and nepotism, which are traditionally considered as characterizing his pontificate
Italian. Nephew of Pius II. Founded the Piccolomini Library in the Siena Cathedral.

Italian. Nicknamed the 'Warrior Pope' or the 'Fearsome Pope'. Nephew of Sixtus IV; convened the Fifth Council of the Lateran (1512). Took control of all the Papal States for the first time. Became Pope in the context of the Italian Wars, a period in which the major powers of Europe fought for primacy in the Italian peninsula. Established the Vatican Museums and initiated the rebuilding of the St. Peter's Basilica. The same year he organized the famous Swiss Guard for his personal protection and commanded a successful campaign in Romagna against local lords. The interests of Julius II lay also in the New World as he ratified the Treaty of Tordesillas, establishing the first bishoprics in the Americas and beginning the catholicization of Latin America. In 1508, he commissioned the Raphael Rooms and Michelangelo's paintings in the Sistine Chapel. Julius II was described by Machiavelli in his works as the ideal prince. Pope Julius II allowed people seeking indulgences to donate money to the Church which would be used for the construction of Saint Peter's Basilica.

Italian. Son of Lorenzo the Magnificent. Closed the Fifth Council of the Lateran. Remembered for granting indulgences to those who donated to rebuild St. Peter's Basilica; excommunicated Martin Luther (1521). Extended the Spanish Inquisition into Portugal. Borrowed and spent money without circumspection and was a significant patron of the arts. Under his reign, progress was made on the rebuilding of St. Peter's Basilica and artists such as Raphael decorated the Vatican rooms. Leo also reorganised the Roman University, and promoted the study of literature, poetry and antiquities. The last pope to not have been in priestly orders at the time of his election to the papacy.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 2 March 1459 Utrecht, Bishopric of Utrecht, Holy Roman Empire (now Netherlands)
Notes: Motto: Patere et sustine ("Respect and wait")[25] The only Dutch pope; last non-Italian to be elected pope until John Paul II in 1978. Tutor of Emperor Charles V. Came to the papacy in the midst of one of its greatest crises, threatened not only by Lutheranism to the north but also by the advance of the Ottoman Turks to the east. He refused to compromise with Lutheranism theologically, demanding Luther's condemnation as a heretic. However, he is noted for having attempted to reform the Catholic Church administratively in response to the Protestant Reformation. Adrian's remarkable admission that the turmoil of the Church was the fault of the Roman Curia itself was read at the 1522–1523 Diet of Nuremberg. His efforts at reform, however, proved fruitless, as they were resisted by most of his Renaissance ecclesiastical contemporaries, and he did not live long enough to see his efforts through to their conclusion.

Motto: Candor illæsus ("Unharmed candor")[26] Italian. Cousin of Leo X. Rome sacked by imperial troops (1527). Forbade the divorce of Henry VIII; crowned Charles V as emperor at Bologna (1530). Commissioned Michelangelo's painting of The Last Judgment in the Sistine Chapel (1533). Approved Copernicus’ heliocentric universe theory (1533). His niece was married to the future Henry II of France (1533). Recognized the Order of Friars Minor Capuchin (Capuchins).

Italian. Opened the Council of Trent (1545). His illegitimate son became the first duke of Parma. Decreed the second and final excommunication of King Henry VIII of England. Appointed Michelangelo to supervise construction of St. Peter's Basilica (1546). Recognized the Order of the Society of Jesus (Jesuits).
Italian. Established the Collegium Germanicum (1552). Reconvened the Council of Trent. The Innocenzo Scandal.
Italian. The last to use his birth name as the regnal name. Instituted immediate economies in Vatican expenditures. The Missa Papae Marcelli composed in his honour.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 28 June 1476 Capriglia Irpina, Campania, Kingdom of Naples
Notes: Motto: Dominus mihi adjutor ("The Lord is my helper")[27] Italian. Member of the Theatines. Established the Roman Ghetto in Cum Nimis Absurdum (1555) and established the Index of Forbidden Books. Ordered Michelangelo to repaint the nudes of The Last Judgment modestly.
Italian. Reopened and closed the Council of Trent. Ordered public construction to improve the water supply of Rome. Instituted the Tridentine Creed.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 17 January 1504 Bosco, Piedmont, Duchy of Milan
Notes: Motto: Utinam dirigantur viæ meæ ad custodiendas ("It binds us to keep")[28] Italian. Member of the Dominican Order. Excommunicated Queen Elizabeth I of England (1570). Battle of Lepanto (1571); instituted the feast of Our Lady of Victory. Issued the 1570 Roman Missal.

Motto: Aperuit et clausit ("Opened and closed")[29] Italian. Reformed the calendar (1582); built the Gregorian Chapel in the Vatican. The first pope to bestow the Immaculate Conception as patroness to the Philippine Islands through the bull Ilius Fulti Præsido (1579). Strengthened diplomatic ties with Asian nations.

Italian. Member of the Conventual Franciscan Order. Known for fixing and completing building works to major basilicas in Rome. Limited the College of Cardinals to 70 in number; doubled the number of curial congregations.
Personal name: Felice Peretti di Montalto, O.F.M. Conv.

Notes: Italian. Supported by the Spanish. Shortest-reigning pope; died before coronation. Set the first known worldwide smoking ban, banning smoking in and near all churches.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 11 February 1535 Somma Lombardo, Lombardy, Duchy of Milan
Notes: Italian. Modified the constitution Effraenatam of Sixtus V so that the penalty for abortion did not apply until the foetus became animated (1591). Made gambling on papal elections punishable by excommunication.
Italian. Supported the cause of King Philip II of Spain and the Catholic League against King Henry IV of France in the French Wars of Religion. Prohibited the alienation of church property.

Italian. Initiated an alliance of European Christian powers to partake in the war with the Ottoman Empire known as The Long War (1595). Convened the Congregatio de Auxiliis which addressed doctrinal disputes between the Dominicans and Jesuits regarding free will and divine grace.[30]
Italian. The great-nephew of Leo X. Called "Papa Lampo" (Lightning Pope) for his brief pontificate.

Motto: Absit nisi in te gloriari ("May it be absent, except to glory in you")[31] Italian. Known for various building projects which included the facade of St Peter's Basilica. Established the Bank of the Holy Spirit (1605); restored the Aqua Traiana.

Italian. Established the Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith (1622). Issued the bull Aeterni Patris (1621) which imposed conclaves to be by secret ballot. Issued the constitution Omnipotentis Dei against magicians and witches (1623).

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 5 April 1568 Florence, Grand Duchy of Tuscany
Notes: Italian. Trial against Galileo Galilei. The last pope to expand papal territory by force of arms. Issued a 1624 bill that made the use of tobacco in holy places punishable by excommunication.

Motto: Alleviatæ sunt aquæ super terram ("Water on earth")[32] Italian. The great-great-great-grandson of Alexander VI. Erected the Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi in Piazza Navona. Promulgated the apostolic constitution Cum occasione (1653) which condemned five doctrines of Jansenism as heresy.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 13 February 1599 Siena, Grand Duchy of Tuscany
Notes: Italian. Great-nephew of Paul V. Commissioned St. Peter's Square. Issued the constitution Sollicitudo Omnium Ecclesiarum that set the doctrine of the Immaculate Conception almost identical to that of Pius IX centuries later.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 28 January 1600 Pistoia, Grand Duchy of Tuscany
Notes: Motto: Aliis non sibi Clemens ("Clement to others, not to himself")[33] Italian. Mediated in the peace of Aachen (1668).

Motto: Bonum auget malum minuit ("He increases good and diminishes evil")[34] Italian. Canonized the first saint from the Americas: St. Rose of Lima (1671). Decorated the bridge of Sant' Angelo with the ten statues of angels and added one of the two fountains that adorn the piazza of St. Peter's. Established regulations for the removal of relics of saints from cemeteries.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 16 May 1611 Como, Lombardy, Duchy of Milan
Notes: Motto: Avarus non Implebitur ("The covetous man is not satisfied")[35] Italian. Condemned the doctrine of mental reservation (1679) and initiated the Holy League. Extended the Holy Name of Mary as a universal feast (1684). Admired for positive contributions to catechesis.
Italian. Condemned the so-called philosophical sin (1690).

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 13 March 1615 Spinazzola, Apulia, Kingdom of Naples
Notes: Italian. Issued the bull Romanum decet Pontificem to stop nepotism (1692). Erected various charitable and educational institutions.
Italian. The Chinese Rites controversy. Patronized the first archaeological excavations in the Roman catacombs and made the feast of the Immaculate Conception universal.[14]

Italian. Prohibited the Jesuits from prosecuting their mission in China ordering that no new members should be received into the order. Issued the papal bull Apostolici Ministerii (1724) to revive ecclesiastical discipline in Spain.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 2 February 1649 Gravina in Puglia, Bari, Kingdom of Naples
Notes: Italian. Member of the Dominican Order; third and last member of the Orsini family to be pope. Originally called Benedict XIV due to the antipope but reverted to XIII. Repealed the worldwide tobacco smoking ban set by Urban VII and Urban VIII.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 7 April 1652 Florence, Grand Duchy of Tuscany
Notes: Motto: Dabis discernere inter malum et bonum ("You shall deign to distinguish between good and evil")[36] Italian. Completed the new façade of the Archbasilica of Saint John Lateran (1735). Commissioned the Trevi Fountain in Rome (1732). Condemned Freemasonry in In eminenti apostolatus (1738).

Motto: Curabuntur omnes ("All will be healed")[37] Italian. Reformed the education of priests and the calendar of feasts. Completed the Trevi Fountain and affirmed the teachings of Thomas Aquinas; founded academies of art, religion and science.
Italian. Provided the famous fig leaves on nude male statues in the Vatican. Defended the Society of Jesus in "Apostolicum pascendi" (1765).

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 31 October 1705 Sant'Arcangelo di Romagna, Papal States
Notes: Italian. Member of the Conventual Franciscan Order. Suppressed the Society of Jesus in the brief "Dominus ac Redemptor" (1773).
Personal name: Giovanni Vincenzo Antonio Ganganelli, O.F.M. Conv.

Notes: Motto: Floret in domo domini ("It blossoms in the house of God")[38] Italian. Condemned the French Revolution; expelled from the Papal States by French troops from 1798 until his death. The last pope to be a patron of Renaissance art.
Italian. Member of the Order of Saint Benedict. Present at Napoleon's coronation as emperor of the French. Expelled from the Papal States by the French between 1809 and 1814.
Personal name: Count Barnaba Niccolò Maria Luigi Chiaramonti, O.S.B.

Notes: Italian. Placed the Catholic educational system under the control of the Jesuits through Quod divina sapientia (1824). Condemned the Bible societies.
Personal name: Count Annibale Francesco Clemente Melchiore Girolamo Nicola Sermattei della Genga

Notes: Italian. Accepted Louis Philippe I as king of the French. Condemned the masonic secret societies and modernist biblical translations in the brief Litteris altero (1830).

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 18 September 1765 Belluno, Veneto, Republic of Venice
Notes: Italian. Member of the Camaldolese; last non-bishop to be elected to the papacy. Opposed democratic and modernising reforms in the Papal States.

Italian. Opened the First Vatican Council; lost the Papal States to Italy. Defined the dogma of the Immaculate Conception and defined papal infallibility. Issued the controversial Syllabus of Errors. Longest-serving pope since Peter (c. AD 30–64).

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 2 March 1810 Carpineto Romano, Lazio, French Empire
Notes: Italian. Issued the encyclical Rerum novarum; supported Christian democracy against Communism. Had the third-longest reign after Pius IX, and John Paul II. Promoted the rosary and the scapular and approved two new Marian scapulars; first pope to fully embrace the concept of Mary as mediatrix.
Personal name: Gioacchino Vincenzo Raffaele Luigi Pecci, O.F.S.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 2 June 1835 Riese, Treviso, Kingdom of Lombardy–Venetia
Notes: Motto: Instaurare Omnia in Christo ("Restore all things in Christ") Italian. Encouraged and expanded reception of the Eucharist. Combatted Modernism; issued the oath against it. Advocated the Gregorian Chant and reformed the Roman Breviary.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 21 November 1854 Pegli, Genoa, Kingdom of Sardinia
Notes: Motto: In te, Domine, speravi: non confundar in aeternum. ("In thee, o Lord, have I trusted: let me not be confounded for evermore.") Italian. Credited for intervening for peace during World War I. Issued the 1917 Code of Canon Law; supported the missionaries in Maximum illud. Remembered by Benedict XVI as a "prophet of peace".
Personal name: Giacomo Paolo Giovanni Battista Della Chiesa

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 31 May 1857 Desio, Milan, Kingdom of Lombardy–Venetia
Notes: Motto: Pax Christi in Regno Christi ("The Peace of Christ in the Kingdom of Christ") Italian. Signed the Lateran Treaty with Italy (1929) establishing Vatican City as a sovereign state. Inaugurated Vatican Radio (1931). Re-founded the Pontifical Academy of Sciences (1936). Created the feast of Christ the King. Opposed Communism and Nazism.

Motto: Opus Justitiae Pax ("The work of justice [shall be] peace") Italian. Invoked papal infallibility in the encyclical Munificentissimus Deus; defined the dogma of the Assumption. Eliminated the Italian majority of cardinals. Credited with intervening for peace during World War II; controversial for his reactions to the Holocaust.

Date_and_Place_of_birth: 25 November 1881 Sotto il Monte, Bergamo, Italy
Notes: Motto: Obedientia et Pax ("Obedience and peace") Italian. Opened the Second Vatican Council; called "Good Pope John". Issued the encyclical Pacem in terris (1963) on peace and nuclear disarmament; intervened for peace during the Cuban Missile Crisis (1962).

Motto: Cum Ipso in Monte ("With Him on the mount") Italian. Last pope to be crowned. First pope since 1809 to travel outside Italy. Closed the Second Vatican Council. Issued the encyclical Humanae vitae (1968) condemning artificial contraception. Revised the Roman Missal (1969).
Personal name: Giovanni Battista Enrico Antonio Maria Montini

Name: English· Latin: Bl. John Paul I[39]IOANNES PAVLVS Primus
Date_and_Place_of_birth: 17 October 1912 Forno di Canale, Belluno, Italy
Notes: Motto: Humilitas ("Humility") Italian. Abolished the coronation and opted for the papal inauguration. First pope to use 'the First' in papal name; first with two names for two immediate predecessors. Last pope to use the sedia gestatoria.

Name: English· Latin: St John Paul IIIOANNES PAVLVS Secundus
Notes: Motto: Totus Tuus ("Totally yours") Polish, first pope of Slavic origin. First non-Italian pope since Adrian VI (1522–1523). Travelled extensively, visiting 129 countries during his pontificate. Second-longest reign after Pius IX. Founded World Youth Day (1984) and the Pontifical Academy of Social Sciences (1994). Canonized more saints than all his predecessors. Youngest individual to start his papacy since Pius IX (1846).

Motto: Cooperatores Veritatis ("Cooperators of the truth") German. Still alive. Oldest to become pope since Clement XII (1730). Elevated the Tridentine Mass to a more prominent position and promoted the use of Latin; re-introduced several disused papal garments. Authorized the creation of Anglican ordinariates (2009). First pope to renounce the papacy on his own initiative since Celestine V (1294),[40] becoming pope emeritus.[41] Longest-living pope on record.

Motto: Miserando atque Eligendo ("Lowly but chosen", literally 'by having mercy, by choosing him')[42] Argentine. First pope to be born outside Europe since Gregory III (731–741) and the first from the Americas; first pope from the Southern Hemisphere. First pope from a religious institute since Gregory XVI (1831–1846); first Jesuit pope. First to use a new and non-composed regnal name since Lando (913–914). First pope to visit and celebrate a mass on the Arabian Peninsula.[43] Restricted the celebration of the Tridentine Mass (2021). Second-oldest verified pope in office after Leo XIII.

Motto: In illo Uno unum ("In the One, [we are] one") Dual American and Peruvian citizen; first pope born in the United States, first from North America, and the second from the Americas.[48][49] Second pope from an English-speaking country; the first since Adrian IV (1154–1159).[50] First pope to be born after World War II and during the Cold War.[51] First Augustinian pope.
